title: Pump Station Safety Manual - Chapter 3: Emergency Shutdown Procedures
content:
EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN PROCEDURES FOR PUMP STATIONS

Purpose: This procedure establishes the steps required to safely shut down pump stations during emergency situations including equipment failure, flooding, fire, or power loss.

Scope: Applies to all pump stations including P-104, P-105, P-201, and P-301.

IMEDIATE ACTIONS:

1. ALARM ACKNOWLEDGMENT
- Acknowledge all SCADA alarms immediately
- Notify Central Control Room of emergency condition
- Activate emergency lighting if required

2. ASSESS THE SITUATION
- Identify the nature of emergency (mechanical failure, electrical fault, flooding, fire)
- Determine if immediate evacuation is required
- Check for personnel injuries or hazards

3. EMERGENCY STOP PROCEDURE
- Press red EMERGENCY STOP button on control panel
- Pumps will stop immediately (no controlled ramp-down)
- All motor starters will open
- Generator auto-start will activate if configured

4. ELECTRICAL ISOLATION
- Open main disconnect switch at panel C-701
- Verify all motors have stopped rotation
- Check motor temperatures - allow 30 minutes cooling before restart
- Post "DO NOT OPERATE" tags on all disconnects

5. MECHANICAL ISOLATION
- Close suction valve V-401 if pump failure occurred
- Open bypass valves if available to maintain service
- Check for vibration, unusual noise, or leaks
- Document pump hour meter readings

WARNING: Never attempt to restart pumps until root cause is identified and corrected. Pumps running dry or with mechanical failure can cause catastrophic damage within seconds.

6. NOTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS
- Notify Water Operations Supervisor: John Martinez (555-0104)
- For after-hours: Call emergency on-call rotation
- Notify Maintenance if mechanical failure suspected
- Document all actions in shift log

7. SYSTEM MONITORING
- Monitor system pressure via SCADA
- Check storage tank levels (T-401, T-402)
- Activate backup pump P-105 if P-104 failed
- Ensure distribution system maintains minimum 35 PSI

DO NOT RESTART until authorized by Operations Supervisor and root cause is resolved.

Related Documents: SOP-PUMP-001, LOTO-PUMP-003
Revision: 3.2
Effective Date: 2024-01-15

title: Chlorine Safety Manual - Sodium Hypochlorite Handling and Spill Response
content:
SODIUM HYPOCHLORITE HANDLING AND SPILL RESPONSE

Chemical Properties:
- Chemical Name: Sodium Hypochlorite Solution (12.5% concentration)
- Storage Location: Chemical Tank T-501 at North Plant
- Hazard Class: Corrosive, Oxidizer
- pH: 12-13 (highly alkaline)

PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT (PPE) - REQUIRED:

1. MINIMUM PPE for routine operations:
- Chemical resistant gloves (nitrile or neoprene)
- Safety glasses with side shields
- Face shield when making/breaking connections
- Chemical resistant apron

2. ENHANCED PPE for spill response:
- Full face respirator with acid gas cartridge
- Tyvek coveralls
- Double gloves (nitrile inner, heavy rubber outer)
- Rubber boots with steel toe

DANGERS AND WARNINGS:

WARNING: Sodium hypochlorite releases toxic chlorine gas when mixed with acids. NEVER mix with muriatic acid, sulfuric acid, or ammonia-based cleaners. Mixing these chemicals will produce deadly chlorine gas - a LIFE THREATENING situation requiring immediate evacuation.

SYMPTOMS OF CHLORINE GAS EXPOSURE:
- Burning eyes, nose, throat
- Difficulty breathing, coughing, choking
- Nausea, vomiting
- Chemical pneumonia (delayed symptom)

If chlorine gas detected: EVACUATE IMMEDIATELY upwind, activate ventilation, call 911.

SPILL RESPONSE PROCEDURES:

SMALL SPILL (< 1 gallon):
1. Evacuate non-essential personnel
2. Don appropriate PPE
3. Ventilate area
4. Contain with absorbent pads
5. Neutralize with sodium bisulfite if available
6. Flush area with water
7. Report to supervisor

LARGE SPILL (> 1 gallon):
1. EVACUATE building immediately
2. Call 911 and notify HAZMAT team
3. Notify Operations Supervisor: Sarah Chen (555-0201)
4. Shut off dosing pump B-201 from SCADA
5. Establish 100-foot perimeter
6. Do not attempt cleanup without HAZMAT team

FIRST AID:

SKIN CONTACT: Flush with water for 15 minutes, seek medical attention
EYE CONTACT: Flush for 15 minutes, seek immediate medical attention (EMERGENCY)
INHALATION: Move to fresh air, administer oxygen if needed, seek medical attention
INGESTION: Do NOT induce vomiting, rinse mouth, drink water, seek immediate medical attention

EMERGENCY CONTACTS:
- Emergency: 911
- Poison Control: 1-800-222-1222
- Operations Supervisor: Sarah Chen (555-0201)

Revision: 4.1
Last Review: 2024-11-01

title: Lockout/Tagout Procedure - Electrical Equipment
content:
LOCKOUT/TAGOUT (LOTO) PROCEDURE FOR ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT

Purpose: Prevent unexpected startup of equipment during maintenance that could result in employee injury or death.

Scope: All electrical equipment including pumps, motors, control panels. Assets: P-104, P-105, P-201, P-301, M-501, M-502, E-301, E-401, E-501, C-701.

REGULATORY REQUIREMENT: OSHA 29 CFR 1910.147 - MANDATORY safety procedure.

GENERAL RULES:
1. Only AUTHORIZED employees may perform lockout/tagout
2. Each employee applies their OWN lock - never share
3. Locks only removed by employee who applied them
4. Test equipment for zero energy before work

LOCKOUT/TAGOUT PROCEDURE (8 STEPS):

STEP 1: PREPARE FOR SHUTDOWN
- Identify all energy sources
- Notify affected employees and control room
- Gather locks, tags, voltage tester

STEP 2: EQUIPMENT SHUTDOWN
- Shut down using normal stop procedures
- Allow complete stop

STEP 3: ISOLATE ENERGY SOURCES
- Open main disconnect switch
- Rack out motor starters
- Open control power circuits

STEP 4: APPLY LOCKOUT DEVICES
- Place lockout hasp on disconnect
- Each worker applies personal lock
- Attach "DANGER - DO NOT OPERATE" tag
- Tags alone NOT sufficient - locks required

STEP 5: CONTROL STORED ENERGY
- Wait 5 minutes for capacitor discharge
- Drain pressure from systems
- Block rotating parts

STEP 6: VERIFY ZERO ENERGY (CRITICAL)
- Use calibrated voltage tester
- Test all phases to ground and phase-to-phase
- Test control circuits
- Attempt to start equipment (must NOT respond)
- If ANY voltage detected, DO NOT PROCEED

STEP 7: PERFORM WORK
- Work may proceed safely
- Keep locks in place entire duration

STEP 8: REMOVE LOCKOUT
- Verify work complete, tools removed
- Notify control room
- Each employee removes ONLY their own lock
- Restore disconnects, test operation

PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS:
- First offense: Written warning
- Second offense: 3-day suspension
- Third offense: Termination
- Removing another's lock: Immediate termination

Revision: 5.0
Effective: 2024-03-01

title: Confined Space Entry Procedure - Storage Tanks
content:
CONFINED SPACE ENTRY PROCEDURE

Purpose: Establish safe procedures for entry into confined spaces including storage tanks T-401, T-402, T-501, wet wells, and vaults.

Definition: Confined space has limited entry/exit, not designed for continuous occupancy.

Permit-Required Confined Space has:
- Hazardous atmosphere potential
- Engulfment hazard
- Internal configuration creating entrapment

All tanks classified as Permit-Required Confined Spaces.

ENTRY PROHIBITION:
- NO ENTRY without valid permit
- NO ENTRY without atmospheric testing
- NO ENTRY without trained attendant

ATMOSPHERIC HAZARDS:

Oxygen: Acceptable 19.5% - 23.5%
- Below 19.5%: Risk of unconsciousness/death

Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S):
- Acceptable: 0 PPM (zero tolerance)
- 100 PPM: Immediately dangerous to life
- WARNING: Paralyzes sense of smell at high concentrations

Carbon Monoxide (CO):
- Acceptable: 0-35 PPM
- 1600 PPM: Death in 1 hour

Combustible Gases (Methane):
- Acceptable: 0-10% LEL
- Above 10% LEL: EVACUATE - explosion risk

PERMIT SYSTEM:
Required info: Space ID, purpose, date, authorized entrants, attendant, supervisor, test results, rescue availability.
Valid for single shift only (max 8 hours).

ENTRY PROCEDURE:

1. ATMOSPHERIC TESTING (Before Entry):
- Test order: Oxygen, Combustibles, Toxics
- Test from outside using sample probe
- Test multiple levels (top, middle, bottom)
- Continuous monitoring during entry

2. VENTILATION:
- Mechanical ventilation required
- Minimum 10 air changes before entry
- Continue during entire entry

3. ISOLATE HAZARDS:
- Lockout/tagout all equipment
- Close and lock valves
- Blank/blind pipe flanges
- Post warning signs

4. PPE:
- Full body harness with retrieval line
- Hard hat, safety glasses, boots
- Respirator if required by testing

5. COMMUNICATION:
- Two-way radio or intercom
- Backup whistle

ENTRY TEAM ROLES:

Supervisor: Issues permit, verifies precautions, terminates if unsafe
Entrant: Trained, aware of hazards, maintains communication
Attendant: Remains outside, monitors entrants, summons rescue, NEVER leaves post

RESCUE:

NON-ENTRY RESCUE (Preferred):
- Harness connected to retrieval line
- Mechanical winch outside
- Attendant retrieves without entering

WARNING: More deaths from untrained rescuers than initial victims. NEVER enter to rescue without training and SCBA.

Emergency: 911
Rescue Team: County HAZMAT (555-9111)

TRAINING:
- Entrants/Attendants: 8-hour course + annual refresher
- Supervisors: 16-hour advanced course
- Annual rescue drill required

Revision: 3.8
Effective: 2024-08-01

title: Electrical Safety Guidelines - Arc Flash Hazards
content:
ELECTRICAL SAFETY GUIDELINES - ARC FLASH AND SHOCK HAZARD PROTECTION

Purpose: Provide guidance on electrical safety when working on energized equipment.

Scope: Transformers (E-301), UPS (E-401), motor control centers (E-501), control panels (C-701).

ELECTRICAL HAZARDS:

1. SHOCK HAZARD: Contact with energized conductors can cause cardiac arrest, burns, falls. Voltage as low as 50V can be fatal.

2. ARC FLASH HAZARD: Explosive energy release during fault. Temperatures exceed 35,000°F. Causes severe burns, blindness, hearing loss.

3. ARC BLAST HAZARD: Pressure wave can rupture eardrums, collapse lungs, throw workers.

HIERARCHY OF CONTROLS:
1. ELIMINATION: De-energize completely, lockout/tagout
2. SUBSTITUTION: Use insulated tools, remote operation
3. ENGINEERING: Arc-rated switchgear, current-limiting fuses
4. ADMINISTRATIVE: Work permits, training
5. PPE: Arc-rated clothing, face shields (last resort)

ARC FLASH BOUNDARIES (Equipment Specific):

Transformer E-301 (1500kVA, 13.2kV):
- Arc Flash Boundary: 8 ft 10 in
- Incident Energy: 12.4 cal/cm²
- PPE Category: 3

Motor Control Center E-501 (480V, 600A):
- Arc Flash Boundary: 4 ft 6 in
- Incident Energy: 6.8 cal/cm²
- PPE Category: 2

Control Panel C-701 (480V, 200A):
- Arc Flash Boundary: 20 in
- Incident Energy: 1.2 cal/cm²
- PPE Category: 1

PPE CATEGORIES:

Category 0: Non-melting clothing, safety glasses
Category 1: Arc-rated shirt/pants (4 cal), face shield
Category 2: Arc-rated suit (8 cal), face shield, balaclava
Category 3: Arc-rated flash suit (25 cal), hood, multi-layer
Category 4: Arc-rated flash suit (40 cal), multi-layer system

INSULATED GLOVES:
- Class 0: Up to 1000V
- Class 1: Up to 7,500V
- Class 2: Up to 17,000V
- Must be tested every 6 months
- Inspect before each use

SAFE WORK PRACTICES:
1. Qualified person requirements
2. Energized electrical work permit required
3. Test voltage detection device first
4. Test all phases and to ground
5. Never work alone on >50V
6. Use insulated tools
7. Remove jewelry

INCIDENT RESPONSE:

Shock Victim:
- DO NOT TOUCH if still in contact
- De-energize if safe
- Call 911
- Begin CPR if trained
- All shock victims need medical evaluation

Arc Flash:
- Call 911 immediately
- Cool burns with room-temperature water
- Do not remove adhered clothing
- Treat for shock

Regulatory: OSHA 1910.333, NFPA 70E

Revision: 2.9
Effective: 2024-09-15

title: Water Quality Monitoring - Safety and Sample Collection
content:
WATER QUALITY MONITORING - OPERATOR SAFETY AND SAMPLE COLLECTION

Purpose: Safe procedures for water quality sampling and online analyzer operation.

Scope: Analyzers S-601, S-602, S-701, S-801 and lab equipment W-101.

SAFETY HAZARDS:
1. Biological: Waterborne pathogens
2. Chemical: Chlorine gas, lab reagents
3. Physical: Slips, confined spaces, electrical

PPE:
Minimum: Safety glasses, nitrile gloves, closed-toe shoes
Enhanced (wastewater): Face shield, apron, rubber boots

SAMPLE COLLECTION:

1. Distribution Samples:
- Remove aerator, clean tap
- Run water 3-5 minutes
- Use sterile 100mL bottles (bacteriological)
- Do NOT rinse bottle (contains preservative)
- Fill to shoulder, cap immediately
- Store on ice, deliver within 6 hours

2. Field Testing:
- Calibrate meters before use
- Test: chlorine residual, pH, temperature, turbidity
- Acceptable chlorine: 0.5-2.0 mg/L
- Acceptable turbidity: <0.3 NTU
- Acceptable pH: 6.5-8.5

ONLINE ANALYZER OPERATION:

Turbidity Analyzer S-801:
Daily: Verify reading, check flow, inspect for bubbles
Weekly: Clean sample cell
Monthly: Calibrate with standards (0.02, 0.10, 1.0 NTU)

Chlorine Analyzer S-701:
Daily: Verify readings, check reagent flow
Weekly: Check reagent color and expiration
Monthly: 3-point calibration (0.5, 1.0, 2.0 mg/L)
Quarterly: Replace tubing, clean pump heads

Flow Sensor S-601:
Daily: Verify reasonable reading
Monthly: Verify zero flow test
Annual: Certified calibration (±2% accuracy)

Pressure Sensor S-602:
Daily: Check for normal pressure
Monthly: Zero and span check
Annual: 5-point calibration (±0.5% accuracy)

LAB SAFETY:
- No food/drink in lab
- No mouth pipetting
- Wash hands before leaving
- Label all containers
- Proper waste disposal

REGULATORY COMPLIANCE:
- Monthly bacteriological monitoring
- Daily turbidity monitoring
- Continuous chlorine monitoring
- Report results within 10 days

Maximum Contaminant Levels:
- Total Coliform: <5% positive/month
- E. coli: 0 (any positive = notification)
- Turbidity: <0.3 NTU (95% of time)
- Chlorine residual: 0.2 mg/L minimum

QUALITY CONTROL:
- Calibrate field meters daily
- 10% duplicate samples weekly
- Proficiency testing monthly
- Acceptable precision: ±10%
- Acceptable recovery: 90-110%

Revision: 4.5
Effective: 2024-10-01

title: Generator Testing and Maintenance Procedure
content:
GENERATOR TESTING AND MAINTENANCE PROCEDURE

Purpose: Safe operation, testing, and maintenance of emergency generators G-301 (500kW diesel) and G-102 (300kW natural gas).

Scope: Emergency generators at South Treatment Plant and Riverside Bridge Station.

SAFETY HAZARDS:
1. Electrical: 480V output - lethal
2. Mechanical: Rotating parts, hot surfaces (>600°F)
3. Fuel: Diesel/natural gas - flammable
4. Exhaust: Carbon monoxide, temperatures >1000°F
5. Noise: 85-95 dBA - hearing protection required

PPE: Safety glasses, hearing protection (when running), work gloves

LOTO: Required for maintenance - lock control switch, transfer switch, fuel supply

WEEKLY TESTING:
Frequency: Every Monday 10:00 AM
Duration: 30 minutes minimum under load

PRE-START INSPECTION:
1. Check for leaks (fuel, oil, coolant)
2. Inspect belts and guards
3. Check battery terminals

Fluid Levels:
- Engine oil: Between ADD and FULL
- Coolant: At FULL COLD mark
- Fuel: G-301 minimum 50% (250 gal), G-102 verify gas valve open
- Battery: Check electrolyte level

Control Panel:
- Switch in AUTO position
- Battery voltage 24-28VDC
- No active alarms
- Record hour meter

START PROCEDURE:
1. Notify Control Room
2. Switch to TEST mode
3. Press START button
4. Engine should start within 30 seconds
5. Warm-up 5 minutes
6. Apply load (30-40% of rating)
7. Monitor gauges every 5 minutes for 30 minutes

ACCEPTABLE PARAMETERS:
G-301 (500kW Diesel):
- Oil Pressure: 45-60 PSI
- Coolant Temp: 180-200°F
- Voltage: 470-480V
- Frequency: 59.8-60.2 Hz

G-102 (300kW Natural Gas):
- Oil Pressure: 40-55 PSI
- Coolant Temp: 170-190°F
- Voltage: 470-480V
- Frequency: 59.8-60.2 Hz

SHUTDOWN:
1. Remove load, return to utility
2. Run 5 minutes at no-load (cool-down)
3. Press STOP button
4. Return switch to AUTO
5. Record run hours and observations

MONTHLY MAINTENANCE:
- Battery load test and cleaning
- Inspect belts (1/2" deflection)
- Check hoses and connections
- Air filter service
- Drain water separator (diesel)
- Exercise automatic transfer switch

QUARTERLY:
- Oil and filter change
- Coolant system check
- Fuel filter replacement
- Exhaust system inspection

ANNUAL:
- Load bank test (100% load, 2 hours)
- Compression test
- Valve adjustment
- Full inspection by certified technician

TROUBLESHOOTING:
Fails to start: Check battery, fuel, alarms
Starts but shuts down: Check oil pressure, temperature
Low power: Check fuel supply, air filter

Emergency Operation:
- Auto-start within 10 seconds of outage
- Monitor remotely via SCADA
- Check fuel level hourly for extended outages

Revision: 3.5
Effective: 2024-07-01
